lines.text: Enter HECTOR and ANDROMACHE

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: When was my lord so much ungently temper'd, To stop his ears against admonishment? Unarm, unarm, and do not fight to-day.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: You train me to offend you; get you in: By all the everlasting gods, I'll go!

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: My dreams will, sure, prove ominous to the day.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: No more, I say.
Enter CASSANDRA

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: Where is my brother Hector?

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: Here, sister; arm'd, and bloody in intent. Consort with me in loud and dear petition, Pursue we him on knees; for I have dream'd Of bloody turbulence, and this whole night Hath nothing been but shapes and forms of slaughter.

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: O, 'tis true.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Ho! bid my trumpet sound!

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: No notes of sally, for the heavens, sweet brother.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Be gone, I say: the gods have heard me swear.

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: The gods are deaf to hot and peevish vows: They are polluted offerings, more abhorr'd Than spotted livers in the sacrifice.

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: O, be persuaded! do not count it holy To hurt by being just: it is as lawful, For we would give much, to use violent thefts, And rob in the behalf of charity.

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: It is the purpose that makes strong the vow; But vows to every purpose must not hold: Unarm, sweet Hector.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Hold you still, I say; Mine honour keeps the weather of my fate: Lie every man holds dear; but the brave man Holds honour far more precious-dear than life. How now, young man! mean'st thou to fight to-day?
Enter TROILUS

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: Cassandra, call my father to persuade.
Exit CASSANDRA

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: No, faith, young Troilus; doff thy harness, youth; I am to-day i' the vein of chivalry: Let grow thy sinews till their knots be strong, And tempt not yet the brushes of the war. Unarm thee, go, and doubt thou not, brave boy, I'll stand to-day for thee and me and Troy.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Brother, you have a vice of mercy in you, Which better fits a lion than a man.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: What vice is that, good Troilus? chide me for it.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: When many times the captive Grecian falls, Even in the fan and wind of your fair sword, You bid them rise, and live.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: O,'tis fair play.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Fool's play, by heaven, Hector.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: How now! how now!

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: For the love of all the gods, Let's leave the hermit pity with our mothers, And when we have our armours buckled on, The venom'd vengeance ride upon our swords, Spur them to ruthful work, rein them from ruth.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Fie, savage, fie!

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Hector, then 'tis wars.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Troilus, I would not have you fight to-day.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Who should withhold me? Not fate, obedience, nor the hand of Mars Beckoning with fiery truncheon my retire; Not Priamus and Hecuba on knees, Their eyes o'ergalled with recourse of tears; Not you, my brother, with your true sword drawn, Opposed to  hinder me, should stop my way, But by my ruin.
Re-enter CASSANDRA, with PRIAM

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: Lay hold upon him, Priam, hold him fast: He is thy crutch; now if thou lose thy stay, Thou on him leaning, and all Troy on thee, Fall all together.

lines.speaker: priam
lines.text: Come, Hector, come, go back: Thy wife hath dream'd; thy mother hath had visions; Cassandra doth foresee; and I myself Am like a prophet suddenly enrapt To tell thee that this day is ominous: Therefore, come back.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: AEneas is a-field; And I do stand engaged to many Greeks, Even in the faith of valour, to appear This morning to them.

lines.speaker: priam
lines.text: Ay, but thou shalt not go.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: I must not break my faith. You know me dutiful; therefore, dear sir, Let me not shame respect; but give me leave To take that course by your consent and voice, Which you do here forbid me, royal Priam.

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: O Priam, yield not to him!

lines.speaker: andromache
lines.text: Do not, dear father.

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: Andromache, I am offended with you: Upon the love you bear me, get you in.
Exit ANDROMACHE

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: This foolish, dreaming, superstitious girl Makes all these bodements.

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: O, farewell, dear Hector! Look, how thou diest! look, how thy eye turns pale! Look, how thy wounds do bleed at many vents! Hark, how Troy roars! how Hecuba cries out! How poor Andromache shrills her dolours forth! Behold, distraction, frenzy and amazement, Like witless antics, one another meet, And all cry, Hector! Hector's dead! O Hector!

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Away! away!

lines.speaker: cassandra
lines.text: Farewell: yet, soft! Hector! take my leave: Thou dost thyself and all our Troy deceive.
Exit

lines.speaker: hector
lines.text: You are amazed, my liege, at her exclaim: Go in and cheer the town: we'll forth and fight, Do deeds worth praise and tell you them at night.

lines.speaker: priam
lines.text: Farewell: the gods with safety stand about thee!
Exeunt severally PRIAM and HECTOR. Alarums

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: They are at it, hark! Proud Diomed, believe, I come to lose my arm, or win my sleeve.
Enter PANDARUS

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Do you hear, my lord? do you hear?

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: What now?

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: Here's a letter come from yond poor girl.

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Let me read.

lines.speaker: pandarus
lines.text: A whoreson tisick, a whoreson rascally tisick so troubles me, and the foolish fortune of this girl; and what one thing, what another, that I shall leave you one o' these days: and I have a rheum in mine eyes too, and such an ache in my bones that, unless a man were cursed, I cannot tell what to think on't. What says she there?

lines.speaker: troilus
lines.text: Words, words, mere words, no matter from the heart: The effect doth operate another way. Go, wind, to wind, there turn and change together. My love with words and errors still she feeds; But edifies another with her deeds.
Tearing the letter
Exeunt severally
